items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

A public hearing is opened to allow an opportunity for public to input regarding the 2013-2014 contract reopener proposal submitted by the Faculty Association, AFT 6157 at the April 23, 2013, meeting of Board.  The openers are:
	 
	 
Article 8 FULL-TIME FACULTY, HIRE DATES AND SENIORITY
	 
8.1 SALARY SCHEDULE INCREASE
1. Increase all faculty salary columns and steps to at least the median of the Bay 10 plus 1 effective July 1, 2013
2. Salary increase for all faculty of COLA and Growth or 3.6% whichever is higher.
           
8.2.2 Intersession and summer pro rata salary schedules for full time faculty for the first 40% load for lecture and lab shall be included as Appendix D-3 and D-4 and Work Experience, Directed Studies and Non-Instructional included in Appendix D-5.
	 
ARTICLE 9 ADJUNCT FACULTY AND SUBSTITUTES
	 
9.1 SALARY SCHEDULE INCREASE
1. Increase all faculty salary columns and steps to at least the median of the Bay 10 plus 1 effective July 1, 2013
2. Salary increase for all faculty of COLA and Growth or 3.6% whichever is higher.
	 
9.13     ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING (moved from 9.20)
	 
Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.
	 
9.14     Pay for Participation in PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT Days ACTIVITIES
	 
9.14.1. Adjunct faculty shall be paid for activities in which they participate, not to exceed three four (4) hours per PD day No adjunct faculty will be paid for both regularly scheduled service and a PD day activity which occur during the same hour.
	 
9.14.2 All adjunct faculty who participate in professional responsibilities including but not limited to: curriculum development, SLO/PSLO development, program review; hiring committees, standing committees, Academic Senate, FA, AFT 6157 shall be paid on the non-instructional salary schedule.
	 
9.18 SENIORITY REHIRE PREFERENCE
	 
9.18.1  Adjunct faculty may attain Seniority Rehire Preference (SRP) status at either 33% or 40% load
            Adjunct faculty  may be assigned a 33% or more load (not to exceed 67% pursuant to Education Code Section 87482.5) may be granted Seniority Rehire Preference (SRP). 
9.18.1.1 SRP status provides a qualified adjunct faculty member with seniority rehire
preference rights over other less senior adjunct faculty within the division. "Qualified"
shall be determined in accordance with section 9.18.2. SRP status does not confer any
rights not specifically identified within this Agreement.
	 
9.18.1.2 The District will strive to provide assignments equal to or greater than a 33%     load for adjunct faculty who attain SRP at 33%.  
	 
9.18.1.3 The District will strive to provide assignments equal to or greater than 40% load for adjunct who attains SRP at 40%. 
	 
9.18.1.4 SRP status does not guarantee a load (i.e. a load is not available, misconduct, performance problems) or provide tenure, permanent status or any employment rights greater than those provided under Education Code 87665.
	 
9.18.1.5 An adjunct faculty member who attained SRP at 33% shall achieve SRP at 40%, after an additional three consecutive semesters of working at a 40% or greater load. Adjunct faculty shall have their SRP load readjusted effective January 2010.
	 
9.22 MEDICAL BENEFITS        
9.22.1  A medical benefit package has been implemented August 2002.
	 
9.22.2  Medical benefits will be consistent with the definition stated in the California
	Education Code, Section 87861 et sec., which defines health insurance benefits to
	include medical benefits but not vision or dental benefits.
	 
9.22.3  The District will provide health benefits to adjunct faculty allowed under Ed. Code Sec. 87861 as follows:
	 
Adjunct faculty must work at least 40% cumulative equivalent of a
		minimum full-time faculty assignment.
Faculty members will pay one-half (1/2) of the monthly premium.
The District will submit a claim through the State for 50% matching funds.
State reimbursement is precluded for adjunct faculty with health benefit
		insurance from another employer. Therefore, adjunct faculty seeking to
		qualify for health benefits must provide certification that no other coverage
		exits.
Adjunct faculty who are eligible for health benefits shall have the option to add coverage for eligible dependents at the employee's cost.
	 
9.22.4  The District exposure will be limited to $50,000. The District will provide the above amount each year as backfill should the State not have enough money to fund the 50% match. 
If in a given year the $50,000 or a portion of it were not needed for backfill, this amount would be used to defray a portion of the faculty memberâs cost in the following year. Each year the District will spend a maximum of $50,000 for this program.
	 
If the backfill exceeds $50,000 in a given year, the District will pay it; however, the amount over $50,000 will be added as an additional adjunct faculty member premium in the following year.
9.27     SICK LEAVE Annual Entitlement, ADJUNCT Faculty
	 
Adjunct faculty shall be entitled, for each semester of service, to a pro-rata of five (5) days of sick leave based on their percentage of load. [See Article 13, Leaves and Absences]. Paychecks for adjunct faculty shall reflect the number of sick hours accrued.  See Articles 13.5.1.4 & 13.5.1.5 for further reference on sick leave entitlement for adjunct faculty. (In process of investigating Sick leave conversion for retirement-may need to open this section).
	 
NEW Section: Implementation of State Disability Insurance:
State Disability Insurance (SDI): Adjunct Faculty payroll deductions will be made to cover the cost of participation  in the SDI plan effective March 10, 2012. 
	 
ARTICLE 11 CALENDARS Article of Choice
Need calendar for 2015-2016
	 
11.5     PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT DAYS           
	 
Normally, four (4) days of the academic calendar year (two one (1) with mandatory attendance) are designated as Professional Development calendar days for the purposes of conducting activities to address critical staff, student, and professional development needs.
11.5.1  Two One Mandatory Day
One (1) Professional Development day each year (in March/April) shall be used for campus-wide convocation at which the president/vice president of the Faculty Association shall be invited to make a presentation.  An additional day, the first PD day in the fall shall be used for activities which may include: campus-wide planning to meet student needs; divisional planning and activities coordinated by the Division Dean; department meetings and activities at which the president/vice president of the Faculty Association shall be invited to make a presentation.  Attendance at the these meetings March/April Campus wide convocation shall be mandatory for all instructional and non-instructional staff.
	 
ARTICLE 12 WORKLOAD, CLASS SIZE, CLASS CANCELLATION âarticle of Choice
	 
12.3.1 Instructional
12.3.1.2 Laboratory Class Assignment.  Twenty (20) in-class academic hours of laboratory per week is a 1.00 FTEF assignment.  Each laboratory class per week is 1/20 or 5% of 1.00 FTEF assignment. Each science laboratory class per week is 1/15 or 6 2/3% of 1.00 FTEF assignment.
	 
12.8     CLASS CANCELLATION
No class shall be canceled if it has a minimum of 20 registered students. Whenever possible, Scheduled classes shall be canceled only after consultation with the instructor.  Classes may be canceled with the consent of the instructor at any time.
           
12.8.1  Without the Consent of the Instructor
	 
12.8.1.1     A class may be canceled within thirty (30) five (5) days before the class starts if the enrollment is less than 60% of the class maximum;
12.8.1.2     During the first two weeks of instruction, a class may be canceled if enrollment is less than 80% of the class maximum;
12.8.1.3     Classes shall not be canceled after the second week of instruction without the consent of the instructor.
	 
ARTICLE 17 BENEFITS
The District shall continue to pay the full cost of any increases in all health and welfare benefits. There will be no monetary Cap on medical benefits listed in the contract to have ensure comparable benefits with the other bargaining unit.- Delete Dollar Amounts
	 
	 
ARTICLE 18 RETIREMENT
The District shall continue to pay the full cost of any increases in all health benefits for retirees. There will be no monetary Cap on medical benefits listed in the contract to ensure comparable benefits with the other bargaining unit.  Delete Dollar Amount

Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees.  Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval.  All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the current bid limit of $83,400 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.

items.item_details:
The voters of California approved Proposition 30, The Schools and Local Public Safety Act of 2012, which created the Education Protection Account (EPA).  Funds received from the EPA cannot be spent on administrative salaries and benefits or any other administrative costs.
	 
The District currently estimates to receive $1,389,322 from the Education Protection Account in FY 2012-2013.  
	 
On April 3, 2013, the District received the attached notification from the California Community College's Chancellor's Office advising that the governing board is required to make a spending determination in open session of a public meeting.  Accordingly, the Board of Trustees is asked to approve that the spending of the funds received from the Education Protection Account be offset by instructional expenditures already included in the FY 2012-2013 Adopted Budget, which was adopted by the Board of Trustees at its meeting of September 11, 2012, because the FY 2012-2013 Adopted Budget assumed the passage of Proposition 30.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the spending of funds received in FY 2012-2013 from the Education Protection Account on instructional activities.

On October 9, 2012 the board approved a Contract with Radiant Electric, Inc. in the amount of $1,585,000 for upgrades to the primary electrical service at Evergreen Valley College.  During construction of that work, various operational upgrades and replacement of equipment have been required, certain components were revised due to availability of parts, and the use of contract allowances were not required to the level anticipated. 
	 
Upgrades, replacement and revisions included:
-  Transformer splicing in Gullo
-  Cable repairs within Sequoia
-  Additional wire racking
-  Fire watch
-  Glastic material
-  Additional fuses
-  Conduit sealing
-  Costs due to delay of shutdown to allow campus operations to close down
	 
Change Order No. 002 includes costs associated with the above items and deduction of remaining allowance funds from the contract.  This change was negotiated for a deductive cost of ($184,557) for a revised contract value of $1,414,733.
	 
The total value of contract change orders including this change represents -11% of the original contract amount.

At the Board meeting held March 13, 2012 the Board was presented information and details by the Program Management team on alternative delivery methods including Design-Build. 
	 
Design-build is a qualifications-based selection process based on either a “pure qualifications-based selection” or a combination of qualifications and fees.  In this process the District hires an architect to develop a set of documents (similar in detail to Design Development drawings) that establish the “Basis of Design” for the Project.  These documents are then utilized in the selection of the Design Build team, a single entity (comprised of a design firm and builder) that agrees to provide final design and construction documents along with construction services to build the project for a Guaranteed Maximum Price within the District’s budget.  Due to the nature of the District Office Relocation project, the design-build delivery method is considered an optimum process to achieve both District influence in the design, and the timely completion of the project in a cost-effective manner.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 051413-3 for utilization of the design-build delivery method for the District Office Relocation/Renovations at 40 South Market, San Jose, a Measure G-2010 Project.

items.item_details:
To comply with with Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) Statements 43 and 45, the San Jose Evergreen College District developed and implemented a Substantive Plan focused on the delivery and funding of health and welfare benefits for eligible retirees and their spouses.
	 
Taxable Other Post Employment Benefits (OPEB) bonds were issued on May 14, 2009, in the amount of $46,775,000 to fund this liability and funds were deposited into the OPEB Trust.  Issuing the bonds ensured that the District complied with GASB Statements 43 and 45, allowed the District to determine how the benefit costs and long-term liability would be funded over time, and provided the District with savings to the General Fund.  The District incorporated capitalized interest to provide two years without any OPEB-related debt service payments from the General Fund.  On March 13, 2012, the Board of Trustees adopted Resolution 031312-2 authorizing the re-marketing of the bonds to further reduce the exposure to the General Fund and to lock in a fixed rate for 15 years.  It is estimated that in FY 2012-2013, the General Fund will contribute $783,207 towards the $2.47 million debt-service obligation and $1.96 million in FY 2013-2014, which remains less than the annual cost of benefits of approximately $3.2 million in FY 2012-2013 and $3.8 million in FY 2013-2014.   
	 
An updated actuarial study by Rael & Letson dated June 30, 2011, determined that the long-term liability associated with these benefit commitments was $40,376,440 with net assets of $49,703,700, which means that the liability was over-funded as of June 30, 2011, by $9,327,260.  Another actuarial study will be conducted as of June 30, 2013, by Nyhart Elpler, which will provide an updated snapshot of the long-term liability and funding status.
	 
The Retirement Board of Authority (RBOA) oversees and implements the OPEB Trust, which has a targeted net investment rate of return of 7.88%.  Attached for reference are the updated actuarial report dated June 30, 2011; the investment portfolio as of March 31, 2013, illustrating assets of $48,509,703; the performance letter dated April 24, 2013, from Benefit Trust; and the presentation from the RBOA.

items.item_details:
This information item will provide a status update on the Measure G-2010 bond program, including background and history on the Program and Construction Management (PM/CM) selection process for the Measure G-2010 bond program, a review of Gilbane's performance through year two (FY2012/13) and information relating to the renewal of Gilbane's agreement for year three (FY2013/14). 
	 
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  On January 25, 2011 a facilities and bonds study session served as an opportunity to share a framework for success for Measure G-2010.  Included in this framework was the recommendation that the District utilize a program and construction management firm to provide program and construction management services to the colleges and District to support implementation of various construction and deferred maintenance projects. In keeping with the District's desire to promote accountability, efficiency and cost effectiveness, the District went through a formal Request for Qualifications process to seek the services of a Program and Construction Management firm to provide system-wide coordination and oversight of all capital improvement work performed under the Measure G-2010 bond program.  Gilbane Building Company was selected through this process.
	 
Since the initial one-year contract with Gilbane awarded by the Board on May 10, 2011, policies and procedures for operating under the Bond have been implemented, overall program and detailed project scheduling has been established and maintained, accounting and purchasing procedures have been put in place and numerous projects have commenced design and are going into construction on the campuses and for the District. Each contract was for time and materials only at a not-to-exceed amount, with the second year value of $4,646,050.  The agreement has the option to renew annually through 2018.  The Board of Trustees approved the initial contract on May 10, 2011 and year two on June 12, 2012.
	 
The Board is being asked to review this information on May 14, 2013 and then take action on a year three (FY2013/14) contract renewal at the June 11, 2012 Board of Trustees meeting.
